metadata.title: Nano-embedded microstructured FeS2@C as a high capacity and cycling-stable Na-storage anode in an optimized ether-based electrolyte

State Key Laboratory of Advanced Electro School of Electrical and Electronic Engineer Technology, Wuhan 430074, P. R. China hust.edu.cn † Electronic supplementary informa 10.1039/c8ta07571a ‡ These authors contributed equally to th

microstructured FeS2@C as a high capacity and cycling-stable Na-storage anode in an optimized ether-based electrolyte†
Min Zhou,‡ Hongwei Tao,‡ Kangli Wang,* Shijie Cheng and Kai Jiang *
Pyrite (FeS2) is considered an attractive Na-storage anode owing to its abundance, environment friendliness and high theoretical capacity (894 mA h g 1). However, it still remains great challenges to realize an
applicable FeS2 electrode with both high reversible capacity and long cycle life. In this study, micronsized FeS2@C composed of FeS2 nanoparticles uniformly embedded in carbon matrix was investigated as a conversion-type anode for sodium ion batteries by coupling with various electrolytes. It is
demonstrated that the electrolyte formulations, i.e., both solvents and Na salts, play vital roles in the Na
storage performance of FeS2. The combination of NaPF6 and DME was highly advantageous for constructing robust SEI films with high Na+ conductivity, guaranteeing fast and reversible conversion reactions in the wide electrochemical window of 0.005–3 V (vs. Na/Na+). Owing to the fast charge
transfer kinetics and high chemical compatibility between the electrolyte and electrode, the as-prepared FeS2@C could deliver a high reversible capacity of 853 mA h g 1 at 0.2 A g 1 and 459 mA h g 1 at 40 A g 1, a remarkable initial coulombic efficiency of 84.7% and excellent cycling stability with capacity
retention of 83.2% over 1000 cycles. These parameters prove the great potential of FeS2@C in fulfiling commercial demands for wide range of energy storage applications.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
With the growing demand for large-scale energy storage technologies, sodium ion batteries (SIBs) have attracted highly revived interest owing to its advantages of resource abundance and low cost.1–5 However, the large size and sluggish kinetics of Na+ inevitably lead to low power and energy densities as well as inferior cycling performances. Till now, the primary anode materials used in SIBs are carbonaceous materials,6–10 transition metal oxides,11–14 metallic alloys15–18 and metal suldes.19–34 Among these, transition metal suldes (TMS) have been extensively explored due to their resource abundance, robust structure and environment-friendly nature. Furthermore, the theoretical capacity of these materials is extremely high based on the multi-electron conversion reactions.
Pyrite (FeS2), as an easily obtained natural mineral, stands out as a promising Na-storage anode with theoretical capacity of 894 mA h g 1.29–31,35–41 It is widely accepted that as anode in SIBs, FeS2 undergoes intercalation reactions followed by conversion
magnetic Engineering and Technology, ing, Huazhong University of Science and . E-mail: kjiang@hust.edu.cn; klwang@
tion (ESI) available. See DOI:
is work.
hemistry 2018
reactions, as stated below. Generally, the conversion reactions (eqn (2)) suffer from sluggish reaction kinetics and severe structural collapse, thus resulting in poor rate capability and cycling performances.29,30,37
FeS2 + xNa + + xe / NaxFeS2 (x < 2) (above 0.8 V) (1)
NaxFeS2 + (4 x) Na+ + (4 x) e / Fe + 2Na2S (below 0.8 V) (2)
To address these problems, some effective strategies have been proposed by controlling the cut-off voltage to restrain the detrimental conversion reactions.29,30,36 For example, Chen et al. reported that in the voltage range of 0.8–3 V, FeS2 shows an ultra-long lifespan of 20 000 cycles with capacity retention of 90%.30Nevertheless, the improvement in cycling performance is obtained at the expensive of sacricing the reversible capacity as the reversible capacity based on the intercalation reaction (210 mA h g 1) is far from the expected values. To sustain the high capacity of the conversion reactions, reducing the particle size to nanoscale has proven to be advantageous.35,37–39 However, the nanostructured FeS2 particles suffer from low tap density and initial coulombic efficiency, which are also important parameters in battery applications. Moreover, the cycling performance of the nanostructured FeS2 is still unsatisfactory with the lifespan less than 500 cycles. As a result, the development of micron-sized FeS2 simultaneously possessing high

reversible capacity and long cycle life still remains a huge challenge.
It should be pointed out that besides the electrode itself, the electrolyte formulations also play important roles in the electrochemical performances of transition metal suldes, such as reaction kinetics, SEI layer formation and coulombic efficiency.22,31,42 For example, compared with the common used ester-based electrolytes (EC, DEC, et al.), the ether-based electrolytes demonstrate much higher chemical compatibility with intermediate products.30,43,44 In this contribution, a facile onepot solid-state method is proposed for the fabrication of micron-sized FeS2@C composed of FeS2 nanoparticles embedded in a carbon matrix. The Na storage behavior of the as-prepared FeS2@C was investigated in various electrolytes (NaPF6/EC-DEC, NaPF6/diglyme (DGME), NaPF6/tetraglyme (TGME), NaCF3SO3/DME, NaClO4/DME, and NaPF6/DME). It was concluded that both solvent and Na salts can signicantly affect the electrochemical properties of FeS2. Moreover, the combination of NaPF6 and DME enables the best Na storage performance due to the fast charge transfer kinetics and high chemical compatibility between the electrolyte and electrode. In the NaPF6/DME electrolyte, the as-prepared FeS2@C demonstrate greatly improved initial coulombic efficiency of 84.7%, remarkable reversible capacity of 853 mA h g 1 at 0.2 A g 1, strong rate capability of 459 mA h g 1 at 40 A g 1 and superior cycling stability of 85.2% capacity retention over 1000 cycles.

sections.heading: Material synthesis
sections.text: FeS2@C was synthesized via a facile and environment-friendly solid-state reaction method,45 in which ferric citrate (FeC6H5O7) serves as both the Fe and carbon source. Typically, the synthesis route of FeS2@C is described as follows. Initially, 3.35 g FeC6H5O7 and 2.24 g sulfur (S) were dissolved in 50 mL deionized water and 30 mL carbon disulde (CS2), respectively, and then mixed together. Aer evaporating the solvent from this mixture, a gel was obtained, which was annealed at 400 C in Ar atmosphere for 6 h to obtain the FeS2@C nanocomposites. For comparison, pure FeS2 was prepared under the same conditions, except FeCl3 (1.62 g) was used in place of FeC6H5O7 (3.35 g).

sections.heading: Material characterization
sections.text:
X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were recorded on an X'Pert PRO Diffractometer equipped with Cu-Ka radiation. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis was performed on an FEI Sirion 200 FESEM coupled with an energy-dispersive Xray (EDX, Oxford Instrument) spectrometer. Transmission electronmicroscopy (TEM) was performed on a JEOL JEM-2010F TEM. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were recorded using an AXIS-ULTRA DLD X-ray photoelectron spectrometer. Nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms were collected at 77 K using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 analyzer and the apparent surface areas were calculated using the BET method. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was performed to
24426 | J. Mater. Chem. A, 2018, 6, 24425–24432
determine the carbon content using an STA 449F5 simultaneous thermal analyzer. Tap density was measured by lling a certain mass of the product in a small measuring cylinder and tapped on for 10 min by hand. The tap density was calculated by the measured volume and mass of the tapped powder.

sections.heading: Electrochemical measurements
sections.text: The working electrode was prepared by mixing the as-obtained products with super P and sodium carboxymethyl cellulose (NaCMC) in a mass ratio of 80 : 10 : 10 in deionized water. The obtained slurry was cast onto a copper foil, dried at 100 C for 12 h under vacuum and cut into electrode lms (diameter, 11 mm). Mass loading on the electrode was 2.4–2.8 mg. CR2025 coin cells were assembled in an Ar atmosphere glove box. To assemble half-cells of NIBs, sodium foil was used as both reference and counter electrodes. Whatman glass ber was used as the separator. The electrolyte composed of 1 M NaPF6 dissolved in dimethoxyethane (DME). In addition, various electrolytes with different solvents and Na salts such as NaPF6/ECDEC, NaPF6/diglyme (DGME), NaPF6/tetraglyme (TGME), NaCF3SO3/DME, NaClO4/DME, NaCF3SO3/DGME and NaFSI/ DGME were investigated for comparison. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements were performed on an electrochemistry workstation (Autolab, PGSTAT302N) at a scan rate of 0.2 mV s 1 at room temperature in the voltage range of 0.005–3 V. The galvanostatic charge/discharge cycling with a cutoff voltage of 0.005–3 V (vs. Na+/Na) at room temperature was measured with a LAND battery test system (Wuhan, China). Electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) were recorded between 100 kHz and 0.01 Hz with an amplitude of 5 mV on a CHI660D electrochemical workstation. The coin cells at the fully charged state were used for the measurements.

sections.heading: Structural characterization
sections.text:
The crystalline phases of the as-prepared FeS2@C were identied by X-ray diffraction (XRD). As shown in Fig. 1a, FeS2@C demonstrates high phase purity with all the diffraction peaks matching well with the standard pyrite phase (JCPDS card no. 37-0475). Based on the Scherer's formula, the mean crystal size of the product was calculated to be 12.8 nm. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed to investigate the surface electronic states and element bonding congurations of the as-prepared FeS2@C. The survey spectra conrmed the existence of Fe, S, C and O elements (Fig. S1a†) as the spectrum of O 1s was derived from the functional groups on the carbon surface. In the high-resolution spectra for Fe 2p (Fig. S1b†), the two photoelectron peaks located at 711.2 and 724.4 eV correspond to the Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 of FeS2 phase. The two peaks located at 163.0 eV and 164. 2 eV in the spectra of S can be ascribed to the S 2p3/2 and S 2p1/2, thus conrming the formation of FeS2 phase. The high-resolution spectrum (Fig. S1d†) for C 1s exhibits only one photoelectron peak at 289.4 eV (C]C), indicating the complete carbonization of citrates. The C content

of FeS2@C was calculated to be 32.4% by thermogravimetric (TG) measurement (Fig. S2†).
Field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analyses were performed to reveal the morphology and microstructure of the asprepared FeS2@C. As shown in Fig. 1b, the as-prepared FeS2@C exists as uneven ake-like particles with an average size of 10 mm. It can be clearly observed in the SEM and TEM images (Fig. 1c, S3†) that the FeS2@C particles are composed of welldispersed nanoparticles with a uniform size distribution of 10–15 nm, which are homogeneously encapsulated in the amorphous carbon matrix. The amorphous carbon matrix can enhance the electronic conductivity of the composite electrode as well as accommodate the volume changes of the active materials during repeated charge/discharge cycles.15,26,35 The high-resolution TEM image of FeS2@C (Fig. 1d) displays clear lattices with spacing of 0.269 nm, corresponding to the (101) crystal planes of pyrite FeS2, which are in good accordance with the XRD and XPS results. The specic surface area of FeS2@C was measured to be 28.6 m2 g 1 based on the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm analysis (Fig. S4†) and the tap density of the composite was measured to be 1.4 g cm 3, which was comparable to commercial LiCoO2.

sections.heading: Sodium-storage behavior in different electrolytes
sections.text:
It is widely accepted that the electrolyte species play crucial roles in the Na storage behavior of metal suldes. To gain insight into the effect of the electrolyte solvent, cyclic voltammetry (CV) and galvanostatic charge–discharge measurements were performed to investigate the electrochemical properties of FeS2@C in typical ether-based and ester-based electrolytes (NaPF6/EC-DEC, NaPF6/DME, NaPF6/DGME, NaPF6/TGME). As shown in Fig. S5,† in the ether-based electrolyte, the FeS2@C electrode demonstrated similar CV features, with four redox peaks located at 0.39/1.38, 0.79/1.8, 1.2/1.97 and 1.6/2.14 V, corresponding to the multiple redox reactions of intercalation
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 2018
and conversion mechanisms. Moreover, in the ester-based electrolyte (NaPF6/EC-DEC), only three pairs of redox peaks can be observed at 0.25/1.6 V, 0.7/2.0 V and 1.3/2.5 V since the FeS2@C electrode suffers from large voltage polarization and rapid CV current decay. It is noteworthy that the redox peaks of FeS2@C slightly change aer the rst cycle, which can be ascribed to the initial activation process and formation of the SEI layers. Moreover, compared with the ester-based electrolyte, changes in the CV curves of FeS2@C in the ether-based electrolytes were negligible in the subsequent cycles, thus indicating higher electrochemical reversibility and cycling stability.
In accordance with the CV curves, the charge/discharge proles of the electrode in ether-based electrolytes are signicantly different from those obtained in the ester-based electrolyte. As shown in Fig. 2(a–d) and S6,† at a current density of 0.5 A g 1, reversible capacities of 830, 796 and 669 mA h g 1 could be obtained without capacity fading over 70 cycles in the ether-based electrolytes NaPF6/DME, NaPF6/DGME, and NaPF6/TGME, respectively. In contrast, cells containing the ester-based electrolyte suffer from rapid capacity fading from 727 to 57 mA h g 1. FeS2 is present in the form of (S–S) 2 bonded covalently to Fe2+, in which the S–S bonds break and reconstruct during the repeated conversion reactions. The drastic capacity fading in the ester-based electrolyte can be attributed to the side reactions between the carbonate solvents and the intermediate product, polysulde (eqn (S1) and (S2)†).22,30,31 It is noteworthy that all the reversible capacities

calculated in this study are based only on the active materials, and we neglected the carbon contribution (Fig. S7†). Moreover, the initial coulombic efficiencies in ether-based electrolytes (79.5–85.1%) were drastically higher than that in the esterbased electrolyte (63.7%). This is of signicance in practical battery applications.
Electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) were recorded to analyze the interfacial resistance and electrode process kinetics in the electrolytes with different solvents. As shown in Fig. 2(e and f) and Table S1,† the SEI lm resistance in etherbased electrolytes is much lower than that in NaPF6/EC + DEC, which is responsible for the formation of a thinner SEI lm and higher initial coulombic efficiency. In addition, the FeS2@C electrode cycled in NaPF6/DME demonstrates the most favorable charge transfer resistance (Rct) of 2.3 U. In the ester-based electrolyte, the Rct increases exponentially from 14.8 to 346.4 U as the charge–discharge cycling proceeds (10th to 30th cycle), which is possibly related to the continuous deposition of carbonates. Therefore, ether-based electrolytes, particularly those using DME demonstrate great advantages in constructing robust SEI lms and attain superior chargetransfer kinetics.
Fig. 3 (a) Charge–discharge profiles of FeS2@C in DME-based electrolyt Electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) of FeS2@C in DME-based electr performances of FeS2@C in the voltage ranges (d) 0.005–3 V and (e) 0.8– cycled with different electrolytes from 0.005 to 3 V after 30 cycles.
24428 | J. Mater. Chem. A, 2018, 6, 24425–24432
In order to further examine the effect of Na salts on the electrochemical performance of FeS2, NaPF6/DME was studied in comparison with NaCF3SO3/DME and NaClO4/DME. As shown in Fig. 3a and S8,† in the rst few cycles, the FeS2@C electrode demonstrates a similar Na-storage behavior in the voltage range from 0.005 to 3.0 V in all three electrolytes (Fig. 3a and S8†). However, the reversible capacity of FeS2@C in NaClO4/ DME and NaCF3SO3/DME decreases drastically aer chargingdischarging for 20 cycles, while the electrode in NaPF6/DME demonstrates decent cycling stability (Fig. 3d). EIS measurements were performed for obtaining further insights into the electrochemical behavior of the electrode in these three electrolytes. As shown in Fig. 3b, c and Table S2,† the RSEI and Rct values of FeS2@C using the NaPF6/DME electrolyte aer the 1 st cycle are 1.3 U and 2.3 U, respectively. These values are much lower than those using NaClO4/DME (207.7 U, 66.8 U) and NaCF3SO3/DME electrolytes (5.7 U, 42.1 U). Aer charging– discharging for 30 cycles, the RSEI of the cells using NaClO4/ DME and NaCF3SO3/DME increased tremendously to 340.8 U and 20.5U, respectively, while the Rct value increased to 297 and 181.2 U, respectively. In contrast, the cells using NaPF6/DME demonstrate decreased RSEI and Rct values of 0.6 U and 1.7 U

aer 30 cycles, indicating the formation of robust and efficient SEI layers with high ionic conductivity during cycling. The composition of SEI layers were characterized by XPS (Fig. S9†). The results suggest that the SEI lms formed in DME-based electrolyte are mainly composed of organic (RCH2ONa) and inorganic (Na2O, Na2CO3, NaF and phosphate) components. It is noteworthy that the XPS analyses indicate an increase in NaF content and decrease in Na2CO3 content in the NaPF6/DME electrolyte compared with those in NaCF3SO3/DME and NaClO4/ DME, which may be responsible for the higher chemical stability of the SEI layers.
Furthermore, the chemical composition of the electrode surface cycled in different electrolytes aer 30 cycles was studied by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS). The S/Fe mole ratios of the electrode cycled in NaClO4/DME and NaCF3SO3/DME were 1.06 and 1.39, respectively, which are signicantly lower than that in

NaPF6/DME (1.95, Fig. 3f, Table S3†). The sulfur loss can be ascribed to the dissolution of polysulde generated during the conversion reactions.43 Compared with that of NaPF6/DME, the severe dissolution of intermediate products as well as the increase in RSEI and Rct values in NaClO4/DME and NaCF3SO3/ DME are responsible for their lower coulombic efficiency during cycling (99.9% in NaPF6/DME; 97.6% in NaCF3SO3/DME; 95.2% in NaClO4/DME) and poorer cycling stability (Table S4†). It is interesting to note that when controlling the cut-off voltage to 0.8–3.0 V, in which the conversion reactions are constrained, FeS2@C exhibited much better cycling performances in NaClO4/ DME and NaCF3SO3/DME, which is comparable to that in NaPF6/DME (Fig. 3e). For further investigation on the inuence of Na salts, the Na storage performance of the FeS2@C electrode was tested in various ether-based electrolytes with different Na salts were tested for comparison. As shown in Fig. S10,† the conversion electrode suffers severe capacity fading aer

20 cycles in electrolytes with the Na salts NaCF3SO3, NaClO4, NaFSI, and NaTFSI. In contrast, in the ether-based electrolytes using NaPF6 (NaPF6/DGME, NaPF6/DME, NaPF6/TGME), FeS2@C undergoes complete and reversible conversion reactions over a wide voltage window (0.005–3 V vs.Na+/Na) with fast charge transfer kinetics as well as high chemical stability, thus resulting in the high reversible capacity and remarkable cycling stability.

sections.heading: Sodium-storage mechanisms
sections.text:
To further reveal the Na-storage mechanism of the FeS2@C electrode in NaPF6/DME, ex situ XRD, HRTEM and XPS characterizations were performed to investigate the crystalline structure and valence states of the electrode at different stages of charge–discharge. As shown in Fig. 4(a and b), when discharged to 0.8 V, the diffraction peaks of crystalline FeS2 disappear and the signals of NaFeS2 emerge in the XRD patterns, thus indicating the electrochemical insertion of Na+ into FeS2 lattice and the formation of monoclinic NaFeS2 phase. When fully discharged to 0.005 V, the XRD patterns demonstrate an amorphous structure of the electrode, while three clear lattices with spacing of 0.21 nm, 0.203 nm and 0.283 nm can be observed in the high-resolution TEM images (Fig. 4c), corresponding to the (100), (101) crystal planes of metallic Fe and the (404) plane of Na2S. Furthermore, in the high-resolution XPS Fe 2p spectra of the fully discharged electrode (Fig. 4e), two new peaks are observed at 706.8 eV and 719.6 eV, conrming the formation of metallic Fe. The results of the TEM and XPS analyses suggest the conversion of crystalline NaFeS2 to metallic Fe and Na2S. It is noteworthy that there are two additional peaks located at 710 eV and 723.5 eV in the high resolution image of Fe 2p spectra, which can be ascribed to the intermediate Na-rich phases of NaxFeS2.33 When fully charged to 3.0 V, lattice fringes with interplanar distances of 0.344 and 0.270 nm are observed in the HR-TEM image (Fig. 4d), which can be indexed to (220) and (200) crystal planes of FeS2. In addition, the XRD pattern and XPS analysis of the fully charged electrode further certify the existence of FeS2. The high electrochemical reversibility of the electrode can not only be attributed to the fast charge transfer kinetics of the electrolyte, but also to the robust structure of the micron-sized electrode, in which nano-sized FeS2 particles are uniformly dispersed in the highly conductive carbon matrix. These nanoparticles provide abundant electrochemically-active nanodomains for fast and reversible conversion reactions, while the amorphous carbon-matrix acts as the physical barrier to guarantee structural stability of the electrode, improve the electronic conductivity of the composite and alleviate the release of intermediate products.
Rate and long-term cycling performances
The rate capability and long-term cycling stability were evaluated in the voltage range from 0.005 to 3 V using NaPF6/DME as the electrolyte. Fig. 5a shows the cycling performance of FeS2@C electrode in the current density range from 0.2 to 40 A g 1. At a moderate current density of 0.2 A g 1, FeS2@C delivered an initial charge/discharge capacity of 1007.5/853 mA h g 1,
24430 | J. Mater. Chem. A, 2018, 6, 24425–24432
corresponding to the initial coulombic efficiency of 84.7% (Fig. S11†). Average capacities of 812, 768, 730, 690, 611, 549 mA h g 1 could be obtained at current densities of 0.5, 1, 2, 5, 10 and 20 A g 1, respectively. Remarkably, even at the highest current density of 40 A g 1, the FeS2@C electrode maintained a reversible capacity of 459 mA h g 1, indicating that a chargingdischarging cycle was completed within 84 s. When the current density switched back to 0.2 A g 1, a reversible capacity of 783 mA h g 1 could be quickly resumed (Fig. S12†). As shown in Fig. 5b, FeS2@C prepared in this study demonstrates much higher reversible capacities at various rates compared with the values previously reported for iron suldes.22,28–38,46
The long-term cycling stability of the FeS2@C is further investigated at the high current density of 5 A g 1. As shown in Fig. 5c and S13,† a reversible capacity of 551.3 mA h g 1 could be obtained aer 1000 cycles, corresponding to a capacity retention of 83.2%. The coulombic efficiency of the FeS2@C electrode rapidly increased up to 99.9% aer a few cycles. In contrast, pure FeS2 without the carbon matrix demonstrated inferior cycling stability with rapid capacity fading aer 400 cycles (Fig. S14†). SEM and TEM analyses of FeS2@C electrodes aer 1000 cycles were performed to examine the morphology changes. As shown in Fig. S15 and S16,† compared with the pristine electrode, for the FeS2@C electrode, the amorphous carbon matrix is maintained well, while the nanoparticles transformed into nanocrystals of smaller sizes, which can be ascribed to the structural decomposition and reconstruction during the chemical conversion reactions. The smaller nanoparticles, which are uniformly dispersed in the amorphous carbon matrix, can facilitate rapid kinetic pathways for ionic and electronic transport in the interior of the electrode. The carbon matrix can effectively accommodate the volume change of the active materials and protects the composite structure from pulverization that occurs during the repeated conversion reactions. In addition, the fast charge-transfer kinetics and chemical stability of FeS2@C in NaPF6/DME over a wide voltage

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: In summary, micron-sized FeS2@C composed of ultra-ne FeS2 nanoparticles was fabricated via a convenient one-pot solidstate method. The Na storage performance of the as-prepared FeS2@C was investigated in various electrolytes. The results reveal that both solvents and Na salts play vital roles. Among the various ester- and ether-based electrolytes, the optimized electrolyte of NaPF6/DME offers the great advantage of constructing robust SEI lms with high Na+ conductivity, in which FeS2@C undergoes fast and reversible conversion reactions. In addition, the well-dened nanoparticles and amorphous carbon matrix can provide rapid kinetic pathways for ionic and electronic transport in the interior of the electrode as well as guarantee the robustness of the structure of the composite electrode against pulverization during repeated conversion reactions. As a result, the as-prepared FeS2@C exhibits a high reversible capacity of 853 mA h g 1 at 0.2 A g 1, a remarkable initial coulombic efficiency of 84.7%, a strong rate capability of 459 mA h g 1 at 40 A g 1 and an outstanding cycling stability with capacity retention of 83.2% over 1000 cycles. This study may pave the way for developing high-capacity and cycling-stable conversiontype electrode materials for prospective energy storage applications.

sections.heading: Conflicts of interest
sections.text: There are no conicts to declare.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: This study was supported by the Natural Science Foundation of China (Grants 21503084, 51622703), the 973 Program (2015CB258400) and the Major Project of Technological Innovation in Hubei Province (2016AAA038).

metadata.abstractText: Pyrite (FeS2) is considered an attractive Na-storage anode owing to its abundance, environment friendliness and high theoretical capacity (894 mA h g ). However, it still remains great challenges to realize an applicable FeS2 electrode with both high reversible capacity and long cycle life. In this study, micronsized FeS2@C composed of FeS2 nanoparticles uniformly embedded in carbon matrix was investigated as a conversion-type anode for sodium ion batteries by coupling with various electrolytes. It is demonstrated that the electrolyte formulations, i.e., both solvents and Na salts, play vital roles in the Na storage performance of FeS2. The combination of NaPF6 and DME was highly advantageous for constructing robust SEI films with high Na conductivity, guaranteeing fast and reversible conversion reactions in the wide electrochemical window of 0.005–3 V (vs. Na/Na). Owing to the fast charge transfer kinetics and high chemical compatibility between the electrolyte and electrode, the as-prepared FeS2@C could deliver a high reversible capacity of 853 mA h g 1 at 0.2 A g 1 and 459 mA h g 1 at 40 A g , a remarkable initial coulombic efficiency of 84.7% and excellent cycling stability with capacity retention of 83.2% over 1000 cycles. These parameters prove the great potential of FeS2@C in fulfiling commercial demands for wide range of energy storage applications.
